intro: Corydalis wyomingensis var. lativaginata, commonly known as the Wyoming poppy, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is characterized by its delicate, funnel-shaped flowers that range in color from pink to red. The plant typically grows in rocky or gravelly soils in arid or semi-arid environments. It has slender, branched stems and lance-shaped leaves that are often covered in fine hairs. This variety is part of the Fumariaceae family and is known for its ornamental value and ecological significance in its native habitat.
